reviews.review_text: Bought the game in the early days for full price, was listed as Multiplayer and promised many features. Multiplayer was NEVER added and none of these features we were told would be implemented, made it in to the game. The Developer secretly worked on the second game behind the scenes, using our money to fund his work rather than finishing the first one and then even having the cheek to Kickstart the second game for even more money? Only to then sell this second game back to us again, at full price! Complete rip-off. Now we're left with nothing but a broken demo. I will NOT be buying the second game and funding such a dirty, cheap money making scheme and I'd advise that others do the same. The only way these developers will learn NOT to cheat their customers, is if they have no custom. As bad as EA as far as I'm concerned.

A fun, aesthetically pleasing space strategy game that is simply awesome!  Or atleast it would be if crucial game elements were fixed.  As it stands, 02-02-2014, several game features are severely lacking in polish and there are some design flaws that really jump out - such as any unmonitored battle being auto-calculated without taking into calculation such things as ship armour or shields, etc. which essentially makes the elaborate, fully customizable ship designing pretty much redundant. Or the way that the AI can win the game without warning due to building a late-game Wonder-style building, which you recieve no notification of until it is already built and the game has ended with your defeat (though this building can be disabled by modding. But it's supposed to be a feature-complete, finished game, right?).  The game still do not feature alterable gameplay options, leaving you with only the options of adjusting video and audio.  The game's features such as customizing races are great, and the shipyard ship-designing is really fun - but if it doesn't matter in the slightest, it isn't really that much of a draw, is it?  I don't really think that I can recommend this game as it is at this stage. It has a lot of really cool stuff going for it, but when crucial elements of the game remains broken, that's really just bad. When (hopefully) they have been fixed or have become toggable (as indeed some of the problems seem to stem from the developer's design decisions), the game is definitely something to recommend. But not in its current stage.

Do not buy Stardrive. This game is an unfinished product. It is, at best, “glitchy”. It's an “early access” with no chance of being fixed. Apparently, for reasons beyond the developer, he isn't allowed to work on the engine of the game any more, or something.  This is rather sad because the game needs optimization, badly. The controls and interface of the game aren't adequate. It makes an obtuse game with a steep learning curve even more convoluted. Basic RTS controls, like finding idle workers or rally points aren't implemented. At least one technology in the science tree doesn't work as described. Ships, especially freighters, lack a good path-finding, making them delay deliveries of vital goods, but it happens to offensive fleets too. Trading technologies requires you look up, -or know the cost by heart-, of everything in the science tree or risk the ire of the IA. The planet managing screen lacks clarity and the possibility for quick changes. The ship building interface refuses to show critical information, like the rate of fire, the global ammunition consumption per second or the global energy consumption. While it can be nice to figure out this puzzle, you have to recalculate everything as soon as you improve your design with new technologies. Having to look up the wiki for vital weapon-data is also unforgivable for a game that requires such precision in its main mechanic from the player. Personalising larger ship becomes a tedious chore. Speaking of ship building, while it is nice to modify them depending on your style, it doesn't take into account how the game works as a whole. The IA isn't a big threat later on in the game as much as it is in the beginning, and that can be circumvented as soon as you realise what variable the computer uses for it's moves: the size of your fleet. Just build a big fleet, and you've won. You don't even need to research, or spend hours personalising cruisers. In the end, it is completely pointless, because you will already be winning by the time you get to bigger spacecrafts, making their puzzle-like personalisation moot and time wasting. Worse, this system isn't as open as it pretends to be: you cannot build viable ships if you deviate from a certain type of fighter. If you are thinking of building a huge flying fortresses which shoots at everything in all directions, think again: one ship attacks one ship. Sure, the area of effect damage might hit others too, but that's leaving it up to chance, or worse, the IA. The attacks your ships employ are always the same: charge! There is an option to turn on a “broadside” tactic but it doesn't work according to the forums.  When you get right down to it, the changes you make to your ships are quantitative, not qualitative. You decide the weapons and the defences, and how much of each, and then try to figure out the best way to power the whole thing and keep sufficient ammunition. In essence, this more open system is just more complex than the one in Endless Space, replacing the straightforwardness of it with inconvenient and pointless creation tools. Also, Endless Space has more tactics  during  the combat phases, with three different phases, defining tactics for each, heroes and hero abilities. In Endless Space, the ships are not just flying towards each other like a Middle Age jousting competition.  It's a shame since Stardrive sounds good on paper. A better IA and path-finding across the board would have gone a long way. An IA that changes tactics depending on difficulty, rather than giving it a boring bonus to resources to compensate for it's inadequacies, would also give a more organic and challenging experience. Being able to annexe other civilizations peacefully by building a federation is great but removes diversity from the game world, by having the player taking control over the planets and fleets of the ally, making end game seem even more without challenge when you suddenly control half the map.   Finally, on a positive note, the aesthetic of the game, the design of the races and the ships, are very pleasing and enjoyable even thought there are basically references to other media (like the Wing Commander series, the mythos of Cthulhu, the Asari from Mass Effect, etc.). The mixture of all the references kind of creates its own style. The rest of the game though needed a lot more polish.

Not a bad concept as this game is quite different than traditional 4x games, but honestly this game just feels too 'small' to be anything other than a bargin bin, $5 time waster. Here's why:  1) You can discover the entire galaxy with literally your first scout ship with almost no impunity. No need to develop a drive or anything.   2) You can seemingly spend your time waiting on research building way points that connect virtually everywhere (seemingly no drawbacks or economic penalty for doing this).  3) Economy is ENTIRELY population based. Expanding your empire's economy relies on you NOT building any actual buildings (at least early). Maintenance costs on buildings that are designed to increase food, defenses, or production ALL drain more out of your income than actual ships, so it's better to just colonize and send colonists and food to the planets for seemingly forever till they have enough people to grow. Just a bizarre concept that doesn't feel rational to me, there really is no option to have a small, but robust empire. It's zerg expansion or die.   4) Conquering enemies, likewise, involves nothing more than zerg tactics (i.e. spamming smallers missle ships and troops). All you have to do is land more troops on the planet than the enemy has and it's soon yours, you can actaully do that by flying right past their defense fleet and zerg landing while a small number of attacks ships keeps their fleet busy. Very silly strat but works easily.  5) Diplomacy is haywire. People either love you to death regardless of your actions or they want to murder you out right. Then they simply want to join with you or your enemy, effectively taking the diversity out of the galaxy and matching one big against another big. Really saps the interest in the game.   6) Ship design is convoluted and seemingly pointless. You don't know what you need to put and where and there is no manual whatsoever to figure it out. Simply putting a power source on a ship isn't enough, you need to add wiring that connects the guns or the shields or the bridge to that power source....at the expense of things like armor. It's like a really terrible game of minesweep to be honest and I like complexity in games, I play 4x games and Paradox games like EU, CK2, and Hearts of Iron....but this ship design leaves me baffled.  All in all, this just feels like a very incomplete game that could have been much better if things like the economy and diplomacy had been fleshed out. The battle system is fun to an extent, but it boils down to zerg tactics. Bring enough cheap to produce missle frigates and focus fire for the win, leave the tactics at home.   I can't recommend this game.

It does not matter what anyone else tells you: this game is not finished and has been abandoned by the developer. It will never be finished nor its bugs fixed. Some of these bugs are game-breaking and there are many features that are either incomplete (to name but one: game mode. You can choose it when you start a new game, you get to choose only one option, though -_-) or inexistant.  Now to the game itself, it is an ok game that appears to be a rip-off of a lot of games, but the ship designer as well as space battles are genuinely fun. I would almost call the initial ships being crappy a stroke of genius since it gives you a nice challenge to build good ships for each faction and possible tech configurations etcetera, this part is really fun. The automation of building them is ok, and putting them in fleets is very nicely done with the fleets manager.  The gameplay itself, not so much. You initially start with one planet, and the one whom colonizes the most suitable planets the first is generally the first to win. If your race has improved metabolism that is every planet with 0.8+ fertility. Mind you those planets tend to be rare (10-15% of all colonizable planets I think?), which only makes it worse that you can also choose to make your race cybernetic. Combine that with industrious and improved metabolism and suddenly your requirements have changed to all planets with 0.8+ production instead (assuming 20-25% tax rate). This basically means 75% of all colonizable planets, most of them being uninteresting to other races except the Opteris (cybernetic), mainly for this reason, that race can actually pose a challenge in the hands of the ai. Granted, you can research stuff to make all planets viable for colonization or bother with crappy food transportation, but that goes against colonizing fast.  So combat: by default, you are at peace with every race. If you have troops/fleets in orbit of each of their planets cabable of annihilating them in a few seconds they will not care. If they intercept one spy they are likely to declare war, but with war you get space battles! Still, if you choose the best possible strategy, there will be no space battles: as long as your military strength is higher than your opponents', only the Opteris will ever dare attack you. And even when it is not, half the ai players will generally just seek peaceful relations (pacifist/cunning/honourable ais). There are also planetary battles: capturing planets through troops. Troops cost no maintenance, though, so flooding each of your planets with troops is a sure way to win: the ai will never bomb your planets.  Remember the game-breaking bugs? One of them involves unlimited production! It involves having shipyard, you spend 10 spare production on a ship, get 13 invested, cancel it, and now you have 13 spare! The shipyard effect even stacks with multiple shipyards, so I don't think I need to tell you how horrible it is to leave this bug in the game.  Overall I give this game a 4.0/10 Kicking dumb ai asses does make me feel better, but you are better off with something like Distant Worlds.

Wow. Stardrive. So sad. Early access is a double-edged sword. On one hand, you get to watch a promising game grow into something really special. On the other, you have Stardrive: A great concept lead by a thief. We were promised bug fixes, more content, and multiplayer. Instead, the dev took our money, discontinued development on this game, and moved on to Stardrive 2. He promises a 33% discount on the sequel for everyone who bought into his scheme. He will not be getting anymore of my money. It's a shame really as the game had a lot of potential.   As it stands Stardrive is okay. Not great. Not good. Just okay. A real-time 4x with fully customizable ships? Sounds awesome! It totally would be if it wasn't for all the game-breaking bugs, stupid AI, performance issues, and lack of multiplayer. All of which were promised to be addressed before the dev took our money and ran.   For around the same price you can grab countless other 4xs that are worth your time and are made by people deserving of your money. Let this game be a lesson to always be wary with early access titles.

tl:dr There are no credits anywhere in StarDrive. I'm not surprised. I wouldn't want to put my name to this crap either. And don't buy StarDrive 2 either.   I've read a lot of the reviews for this game and they all read much the same, that it was the product of a lone developer who took the money and ran before the game was finished, but not many actually talk about the game beyond 'it could have been great!' So to give some insight into what StarDrive is really like:  * Path-finding is appalling - Use alt+click to override if you want your ships to get anywhere as fast as possible. There is also such as a thing as too fast. Keep the FTL under 100K unless you want to watch your ships play ping pong around each destination. * Accuracy of weapons that use munitions is appalling - You can either use beam weapons (and suffer appalling lag) or spray the battlefield with ordnance (and suffer appalling lag) to increase the likelihood you'll actually hit anything. * Ground battles are appalling - Have more troops in orbit than there are tiles on the planet, land them all at once and then let the AI take over and forget about it. Do not bother trying to micromanage the ground battle, it is a waste of time and takes too long, so just wait for the notification saying you have taken over the planet. * Manual ship control is appalling - There is no point of reference when you take manual control of a spaceship, the mini-map does not zoom in to help you navigate and the only way to get some idea of which direction you are travelling is to fire forward facing munition weapons and see which way they drift. It is truly horrific trying to fight using manual control, most of the time you'll just be turning on the spot hoping the enemy ships really will fly into your gunsights. That is if you can even get your ship to stop. * The AI is appalling - Nothing can be done about this, although you can abuse it. You can bombard a planet into nothingness and then leave at least one bomber continually dropping nukes because the enemy will continually try to recolonise it until you have wiped them all out of existence. Also, the AI does not send more than four ground troops at once for a ground assault, so just make sure each of your planets has as many hard troops as will fit. * Diplomacy is appalling - Just make sure you buy alliances before someone else gets there first. * The interface is appalling - There is no way to delete save games from within the game. When I did finally find them the first time I did a manual search of the hard dirve they had consumed over 4GB of storage space. * The lag is appalling - By far the worst problem is lag. You won't notice it at first, but the longer a game lasts the worse it gets (and not always because of large numbers of ships). The most impressive lag I've seen is when the final game stats run. I just get the impression it's replaying the game in the background all over again because how else can you make the final game stats lag so atrociously? It's just a map with three bar charts!  There is loads more wrong with this game, this is just a shortlist of the ones I can remember, but there must be a reason I pumped 78 hours into this monstrosity? Well, I got it in a bargain bin from an actual shop, so didn't see the reviews initially. But, the main reason I wasted so much time on it is modding. People complain about the crappy tech tree and the cookie-cutter planet development. Then just mod it. Literally everything can be modified. I had whole new branches of technology, new ship hulls (most notably the Borg and a smiley face), new artifacts, new ship modules (from armoured reactors and reactors that were armour, to guns that never ran out of ordnance and armour that was a gun and provided power and never ran out of ordnance), ships that could travel the universe in seconds, new planetary buildings, and so on. Literally everything can be modified, and once you learn how it's not that hard to make a change and then test the effects. Unless you make a mistake, then the game fails to load. Even then, with a little practice, you begin to learn how to read the error message. It is even possible to modify armageddon and have a game that never ends. (Which actually means ends when it crashes.)  So given all that potential for making improvement why do I not recommend this game? Because once you start rooting through the game files to make changes you begin to notice strange files and folders that hint at missing features and you begin to understand just how much was left unfinished by the developer and the fact they couldn't even be bothered to remove all of this before releasing the game as a finished product. Like a hint at just how much you are missing out on. But worse than that, even though you've modified every single aspect of the game so you can effortlessly hold off armageddon indefinitely, it only works if you micromanage every single battle because the AI is appalling. I did try imagining my ship commanders were just drunk bullies because they always go after the smallest, weakest enemy ship (fleet orders reset to defaults as soon as you close the fleet setup screen), expertly missing them even though you've modified the Vulcan into a minigun-shotgun with the range and fire power of a sniper rifle, all the while oblivious to the enemy capital ships playing turkey shoot with them, but I couldn't hold that thought for long because it really is a just crap programming and a crap AI. And indefinite ends when the game decides to crash from out of memory (which is impressive when not even a quarter of the 8GB available on this machine is being used) or you just can't stand the lag any longer and know that the lag in the endgame stats is most likely going to crash the game anyway.  And then you read the reviews for StarDrive 2 and see the pattern repeating and you realise the developer is never going to learn so long as people continue parting with the cash for unfinished products.  Actually, there is one final point to make about this game. I've never before come across a game that didn't have credits somewhere. The credits might run when you complete a game or be hidden somewhere in the menu, but they are always there somewhere. There are no credits anywhere in StarDrive. I'm not surprised. I wouldn't want to put my name to this crap either.

From the brief time of early access to the first release of the game, there was no new update, since then, it has only been minor tweaks, few and far between. Before early access, there was promises of a fully fleshed out experience. During early access, those promises remained. A few moments after first release, the dev stated that he will no longer be working on this game, so he may have time on his newer game which will be almost exactly like this game, only in a different engine, and hopefully better. He has also said that he plans to give all those who have bought StarDrive a discount on his next game, whenever it's released on Steam. Who knows how much of a discount that will be. Take a risk, buy this game discounted heavily in hopes that it will make the next game cheaper than the full priced original. Play this as the alpha that will never be finished. Don't buy this as a finished game, or even one that you expect future development on.

Realtime 2D Space 4X.   Ship customisation is awesome, planet micro is not. The AI can handle a lot for you which is great (and a must). Ship/Fleet management is overwhelming and not very necessary given Stardrive's game mechanics - which is disappointing. Research tree is unnecessarily complicated (i.e. it is poor but not as bad as Sins of a Solar Empire).   Did you understand all the jargon and enjoy MoO2? - then this is your game. Endless Space is better than Stardrive in all aspects but Endless Space has a completely different ship combat mechanic and is turn-based. If combat is the make or break choice: choose Stardive if you want to control swarms of 2d ships, choose Endless space for battle strategy and awesome combat visuals.   Get it only on sale.

Now that it's been officially released, I am going to recommend to everyone who sees this and enjoys 4X games to give StarDrive a test.  StarDrive is a game of immense depth. You are provided the option of designing your entire fleets to your specifications -- you can create ships using a variety of weapon types and defenses. The game even facilitates some very interesting and not inherently obvious strategies surrounding your ship construction.  The gameplay itself is basically a 4X RTS/TBS hybrid. 'Empire' related things, such as economy, diplomacy, and colony management are done in timed turns where each turn is something like five seconds. 'Ship' related things, such as flight, combat, and eventual destruction are handled in real time.  This game sucked away more than 100 hours my play time before it was even released. It can do the same for you, too, if you would like it to.

I really wanted to like StarDrive. It reminded me of the old Stars! game for Windows 3.1, where you would define your alien race, expand, conquere, research and design new ship layouts. It sounded like a great modern update. But after playing for a while, expanding a lot, and making a large fleet, I tried to attack a small faction and lost for no good reason. It feels like there's a 'correct' way to play this game and they never tell you anything about how to play it. For instance, to conquer a planet, you have to take out the ships guarding it, and then send colonists over in separate transport ships to fight on the ground, which is heavily favoured to the defender. You have to outnumber them like 10-1 to have a hope of taking the place. So after spending an untold effort in trying to take ONE planet from a small faction, my faction gets into a civil war and my homeworld gets heavily attacked, at which point I lost all interest in this game.  The mechanics are clunky and not at all expained. To top it off, it seem like a lot of features where left unfinished in favour of working on the sequel, so overall, I would say avoid. I mean really, 75% of the 4x games on steam are space based like this. Search games by tag and find a good one to play.
